body: **Warning** - These commits modify **unsafe code**. Please review it carefully!
ping @Gankro

:heart: :heart: :heart: 

Thanks so much for persisting! Will review/trick-others-into-reviewing ASAP.
@csherratt I've gone over all the changes. Awaiting response.

I think it would be really nice if a `RingBuf::as_slices()` function were provided that returned `(&[T], &[T])` with either slice allowed to be empty, and with element order of front to back.  There are cases where getting a slice of elements from a `RingBuf` is necessary, but it would be OK to have two separate slices.  Otherwise, it requires copying the elements into a `Vec`.  Also, the iterator implementation could be simplified to a chained iterator over both slices.
By the way- this is awesome!  This was sorely needed.
@danburkert I was planning on doing a similar api later. I don't think using the chained iterator would be faster, it might be simpler.

Okay I think(?) the only problem left is that you've added far too many special cases for zero-sized types. I think the only thing you need to worry about is alloc and free (and be sure you aren't depending on the distance between two pointers of `n` elements).
The benchmarks are bad because they will be optimized away with a better implementation.

If you don't wrap the pointer,

``` rust
            while None != deq.pop_back() {}
```

can be optimized to a single compare and move.
Huh, why was this closed?
LGTM.

I would be interested in seeing some more `debug_assert`s about various invariants, e.g., enforcing that `tail > head` (or whatever that invariant is meant to be) and that the capacity is a power of two.

@csherratt I think we can punt on any more optimizations and the head-tail debate for now. It's already a massive improvement, and I would like to land this for the bug fixes it entails. I believe [this](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/18747#discussion_r20065315) is the only fix left to do. Although the debug_asserts would be good to add, too.

Sadly, `debug_assert` is not currently removed in a normal build since https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/17665 hasn't been implemented yet. It would be nice if we could make extensive use of it but at the moment it would destroy performance.

Correctness > performance, and it is easier to add `debug_assert`s now than go through later and put them in. In my mind, we should be taking a medium/long-term view and writing for the language we will have, not aiming to get everything completely optimised for what we have currently.

Sure it is unfortunate to not be super-fast _right now_ and could lead to some negative publicity, but being incorrect is far worse IMO.
Using `debug_assert!` extensively will result in this being slower in many cases than the current ring buffer. In that case, it doesn't make sense to merge this.

Once #17665 is solved, those problems will go away. We should optimise for the language we are aiming to have, not the one we currently have. It is ridiculously easy to manually do #17665  (i.e. `sed -i /debug_assert!/d ringbuf.rs`) on a case-by-case basis if it is not in-place by 1.0 but much harder to do the reverse if #17665 is implemented.
@Gankro both of the oom cases should be covered by https://github.com/csherratt/rust/commit/3905a39d841bf4db3b3583e94b02b98d6c5616c2

Ah, that it is! (I was going off of clobbered comments) 

Just need to figure out if we want the debug_asserts, then. I leave you in the strong, comforting, arms of  @huonw then.

I added some extra debug_asserts. I was careful in where I placed them to avoid doing the same check twice. The only state that is invalid for the head and tail pointer to be in is if they are greater then or equal to the capacity of ring buffer. Since `wrap_index` is used in every case to modify the head and tail pointer placing an out of bound check in it will check that assertion everywhere.

The other suspect code is the logic in `reserve`. So I added a few extra asserts.

Performance wise the extra checks are not free. The largest changes are in the iteration rate.

**Before**

```
test ring_buf::tests::bench_grow_1025                      ... bench:      3078 ns/iter (+/- 43)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_iter_1000                      ... bench:       629 ns/iter (+/- 4)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_mut_iter_1000                  ... bench:       625 ns/iter (+/- 9)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_new                            ... bench:        17 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_pop_100                        ... bench:       284 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_pop_front_100                  ... bench:       235 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_push_back_100                  ... bench:       282 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_push_front_100                 ... bench:       234 ns/iter (+/- 1)
```

**After**

```
test ring_buf::tests::bench_grow_1025                      ... bench:      2883 ns/iter (+/- 202)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_iter_1000                      ... bench:       999 ns/iter (+/- 15)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_mut_iter_1000                  ... bench:       994 ns/iter (+/- 21)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_new                            ... bench:        17 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_pop_100                        ... bench:       223 ns/iter (+/- 1)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_pop_front_100                  ... bench:       209 ns/iter (+/- 1)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_push_back_100                  ... bench:       220 ns/iter (+/- 5)
test ring_buf::tests::bench_push_front_100                 ... bench:       215 ns/iter (+/- 1)
```

> while None != deq.pop_front() {}

These benchmarks are still useless because they can be optimized away.
Ideally the push and pop benchmarks should handle their inverse with unsafe code so that it doesn't take any time.
@mahkoh that's not a bad idea. I'll give it a try.
I'm happy to r+ this after feedback on https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/18747#discussion_r20143077 (everything else can be done later).
@huonw I think I have satisfied the asserts you wanted.
Can I get a retry? The first build failed because I got unlucky and this got hit by a breaking change #18827

Yessss eat @bors it meeeeerged!

:tada:
@Gankro 4th times the charm.
